text: Family Member: So you can radiate? Doctor: We can radiate anywhere. Family Member: So in C___ Dr. F____ can radiate. Doctor: Dr. F____ can radiate it. If it’s needed. Now, he won't just willy nilly do it unless you have pain, or we've shown that everything about you is stable and those are the only two areas that’s acting up. Family Member: Well, that’s good to know that. I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah see you’re not just out there. Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything”

text: Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: Um. So, let me, uh, check in with I_ to see if she needs to follow with you, uh, because we’ll just stay on drug for now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I put the order in for the blood test. I need to just check to make sure that, with the holiday, that if I draw it, it’s not gonna get lost or be not usable because, uh, nobody’s here to work on it. Patient: Right. Doctor: They only run the test once a week. So, if they’re aware it’s coming today and they run it next Monday, then you’re golden. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, and then, we will set up when you need to come back, but I want you to take a look at these two, read them. We’ll know the AR-V7, hopefully within a week’s time. text: Patient: Well I mean it’s- Doctor: It’s not always like that but it’s possible. Patient: No. No. No. It’s better to know what you’re dealing with than not. What about the treatment side of it in Europe? I mean what do they do once, let’s say you’re a candidate. Then they, do they attach to the uh to the antibody? Doctor: Well, so it’s not an antibody. Patient: Oh. Its an enzyme, enzyme.. Doctor: It’s a, uh, it’s a little very tiny little piece of just a little chemical. Patient: Oh. Doctor: That has enough specificity that it’s a glue to the antibody. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh so what they usually do is uh you go there. They do screening tests including an imaging test. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh they give you a treatment. At least my experience is then they keep you for a little bit and image you maybe once or twice after to look at how much your cancer took up the material.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A month ago, you hadn’t and now you’ve you’ve crossed that number which I think was twenty-six point seven. So you’re two points above that. Doctor: The um the bone scan looks completely unchanged, in other words normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t think there is any evidence or hint that there could be prostate cancer in the bone. Doctor: - which has slightly increased in size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. It is probably due to prostate cancer. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: We won’t know for sure unless we do a biopsy, which I’m not recommending. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It almost would require us putting you back on it, having demonstrated it doesn’t work, and then adding this drug, which is kind of weird. Occasionally, however, we have seen men after testosterone because potentially you could respond to enzalutamide. I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s a little bit confusing but that’s another possible trial. Patient: That’s the extent, enzalutamide? Doctor: Yeah, right. So I mean you didn’t respond. Patient: Well I mean the, the PSA went up a little bit. It went from- Doctor: With the scans. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh and the third trial we have which is the most extreme one, we’re also doing bone marrow transplant trial, which um is way out there. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh we have two men we’ve treated now, your age or younger. Uh that would require you to live here for a couple of months, and it would require a donor, a female, like a daughter, or sister, or cousin.

text: Patient: No. Doctor: Swelling? Bumps, Lumps? Patient: No. No. Family Member: Are those, uh, energy drinks that you see on TV problematic? I’m asking sort of for myself, too. Doctor: Uh. I mean they have a lot of calories in them, and so, uh, it’s more about why he’s takin’ them or Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: I mean, again, if he takes them, he may eat less, but – um. Family Member: Are they just loaded with caffeine or something or? Doctor: Some of them are. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, when we saw you or you had came on April seventeenth, your white count was normal. You are anemic. I don’t think it’s really the iron. It may be your cancer and your treatment. It’s twenty-nine. Normal would be forty-one. Uh, and your platelets are okay. So, the only thing that we see is the low, uh, blood count, blood cells. Um. Your liver looks good. (Pause) Patient: I was on chemo ‘til February? Maybe that’s why the blood count’s down. I don’t know. (Pause)

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
